Here's a speciation/clustering method that may by useful for
speciating ini=
tial populations or respeciating when the number of
species deviates from t=
he target number, e.g. because of an old
species has been culled.

Step 1) =
Assign genomes randomly to a cluster.
Step 2) For each genome calculate its=
 mean distance from the genomes
in each cluster. Move the genome to the clu=
ster it is closest to (if
necessary).
Step 3) Goto Step 2 until no more re-=
assignments are necessary or the
number of re-assignments falls below some =
low threshold number.

There are some graphs in my blog of an experimental =
run using points
in 2D space, see http://the-locster.livejournal.com/43595.=
html

Following this we can probably get a reasonably good initial number
f=
or the compatibility threshold by measuring the distance between
genomes in=
 clusters; since clusters will be roughtly spherical in
shape (hyperspheres=
) we can take the largest distance between any two
genomes in a cluster as =
being an approximation of each spheres'
diameter, and thus the compatibilit=
yy threshold should be about half
this figure. It's just a ball park number=
 to use instead of a fixed
arbitrary number which is typically used at the =
moment.

Colin.
